pr_title: SAK-44763 - Improve URL matching on CC import

timeline.message: SAK-44763 - Improve URL matching on CC import

timeline.bodyText:
If you have a nice URL object, then just re-create it from the URL 👍
new URI(uri.getScheme(),
uri.getAuthority(),
uri.getPath(),
null, // Ignore query
uri.getFragment()).toString();
timeline.author: ottenhoff

replies.bodyText: I really wanted to find a StringUtils that did this :(
replies.author: csev

replies.bodyText: Sam - I just want this to be a string match.  I don't want a bunch of conditional code with ports, etc.
replies.author: csev

replies.bodyText: ok ...... I prefer using the nice URL object because URLs are complex.... but string matching is fine if you know what the URL looks like
replies.author: ottenhoff

replies.bodyText: for example, is the fragment ever used or important ?
replies.author: ottenhoff
jonespm

replies.bodyText: yeah but i'm understanding chuck's concern from the phone call: the URL can't change at all because it's part of the hash..... so putting the URL through any type of processing doesn't make sense.
replies.author: ottenhoff

replies.bodyText: I took Matt's suggestion, wrapped in a really cranky unit test - and the URIBuilder code passed with flying colors.   It handles al the things I expected it to handle and then some.  I think it tweaked less than a URL processor because URIs are more strings than URLs - but they do know how to pitch a query string.  So that turned out nicely.
replies.author: csev

timeline.message: SAK-44763 - Change priority to all local first, unit test

timeline.bodyText: use log.debug much better than System.out
timeline.author: ern

replies.bodyText: There were just a few - they are gone now - thanks.
replies.author: csev

timeline.message:
SAK-44763 - Use URIBuilder to remove the query

Per Matt Jones.
